posts.com:
guys.
i've tried the openai codex models to generate python code from english.
this thing generates simple scripts that work like two times out of three.
the better you task it with easy steps and clear instructions, the better it works.
also, the assholes at OpenAI are not the only ones, there are other projects allowing you to work using prompts.

despite it being experimental and early in progress, I can safely say that 90% of todays programmers will be out of a job in 5 years.
there, I said it. because its fucking obvious and the writing is on the wall.

posts.com: Are you sure you're not just saying that cause I said it earlier...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
really, we are making the same step we did from assembler to c, from c to python. now its writing python to writing prompts.

we are continuing our quest for more abstraction. same thing as with python was already very abstract, supported multiple paradigms etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
for stuff that really counts such as high priority c or c++ code where speed is important, it will always be here. but fuck I dread the day when ai will write actual working C programs.
imagine it will be compiled on the fly and the source code will be thrown away because "who would read it anyway?"
everything will have to be reverse-engineered so basically, we are moving towards hell, chaos and resignation of the human species.

ai will be fun for a while as a novely but sooner or later our growing incompetence will wake us up from the sleep we are lulled into.
our incompetence will become a wake up call because lets face it. There will be way less reason to actually practice certain skills.
our brain needs to work and process information. I am not saying its going to destroy us completely but for sure, it is bringing us closer to total apathy.
it will affect very central core features of the human experience like ambition, drive, curiosity, effort etc.
we are messing with things that shaped us to what we are now.
without these things, we would still be in the trees.
problem is, I doubt we will go back to the trees.
It is more probable that we just have to live the plot from Idiocracy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: imagine if every mcdonalds worker was a free scientist even if u were dumb ud make minor contributions... the world would advanced so much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90283706
except very few mcdonalds workers have any clue as to what is the most efficient way to structure a program.

the AI still has to be aware of these things for the average guy to be able to use it.
my point is: unless the mcdonalds random guy knows these things, someone else has to know them or else the generated code will be shit.

but that is the current state,
I am sure later on, the generated code will be secure and shit but then it defeats the purpose of being general.
right now, codex was trained on github. that means all kinds of programming styles and errors would be included.

for a mcdonalds worker to make software with prompts, the model needs to be trained on the highest quality software available, not on random github stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I am not saying everything is bleak but I think we will simply resort to training the AI on other AI stuff and we will end up with black boxes everywhere.
and that will be the end of general programming as we know it.

negative prompt: "loli, moe, (deformed:1.5), (extra arms, extra limbs, extra legs:2),\
  \ (2girls:1.5), (text), (mutated:1.5), poorly drawn, bad proportions,\n  badly drawn\
  \ face, (cropped:2), (sfw:1.2), (cum,jizz,semen,bukkake:3), (badly drawn hands:5),\

looks like chell from portal, faith connors from mirrors edge, chun-li from street fighter, revy from black lagoon)

This one sucked. Started with an aborted attempt to make a tree, but didn't work very well! Barely made it...
bool cmp(string l, string r) {
    int i = 0, j = 0, n, ln, rn; size_t z;
    while (i < l.size() && j < r.size()) {
        if (l[i] == ']' && r[j] != ']') {
            return true;
        }
        if (l[i] != ']' && r[j] == ']') {
            return false;
        }
        if (isdigit(l[i]) && r[j] == '[') {
            n = stoi(l.substr(i),&z);
            l.insert(i+z,"]");
            l.insert(i,"[");
        }
        if (l[i] == '[' && isdigit(r[j])) {
            n = stoi(r.substr(j),&z);
            r.insert(j+z,"]");
            r.insert(j,"[");
        }
        if (isdigit(l[i]) && isdigit(r[j])) {
            ln = stoi(l.substr(i),&z);
            i += z-1;
            rn = stoi(r.substr(j),&z);
            j += z-1;
            if (ln < rn) {
                return true;
            }
            if (rn < ln) {
                return false;
            }
        }
        i++; j++;
    }
    return false;
}

int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {
    ifstream f("input.txt");
    string s, l, r; size_t z;
    int i, j, n, ln, rn, idx = 1, sum = 0, d1, d2;
    vector<string> pkts = {"[[2]]","[[6]]"};

    while (f >> l >> r) {
        pkts.push_back(l);
        pkts.push_back(r);
        i = 0, j = 0;
        while (i < l.size() && j < r.size()) {
            if (l[i] == ']' && r[j] != ']') {
                sum += idx;
                break;
            }
            if (l[i] != ']' && r[j] == ']') {
                break;
            }
            if (isdigit(l[i]) && r[j] == '[') {
                n = stoi(l.substr(i),&z);
                l.insert(i+z,"]");
                l.insert(i,"[");
            }
            if (l[i] == '[' && isdigit(r[j])) {
                n = stoi(r.substr(j),&z);
                r.insert(j+z,"]");
                r.insert(j,"[");
            }
            if (isdigit(l[i]) && isdigit(r[j])) {
                ln = stoi(l.substr(i),&z);
                i += z-1;
                rn = stoi(r.substr(j),&z);
                j += z-1;
                if (ln < rn) {
                    sum += idx;
                    break;
                }
                if (rn < ln) {
                    break;
                }
            }
            i++; j++;
        }
        idx++;
    }

    sort(pkts.begin(),pkts.end(),cmp);
    for (i = 0; i < pkts.size(); i++) {
        if (pkts[i] == "[[2]]") {
            d1 = i+1;
        }
        if (pkts[i] == "[[6]]") {
            d2 = i+1;
        }
    }

    cout << "P1: " << sum << endl;
    cout << "P2: " << d1*d2 << endl;

    f.close();
    return 0;
}

posts.com:
Part 1
data = open("Day 14 input.txt", "r").read().replace(" -> ", " ").split("\n")

grid = set()
for line in data:
    coords = [map(int, i.split(",")) for i in line.split()]
    pos = coords[0]
    for target in coords[1:]:
        if pos == coords: #just in case
            continue
        if pos[0] == target[0]: #same X - vertical line
            step = [0, 1 if target[1] > pos[1] else -1]
        elif pos[1] == target[1]: #same Y - horizontal
            step = [1 if target[0] > pos[0] else -1, 0]
        
        grid.add(tuple(pos))
        while pos != target:
            pos[0] += step[0]
            pos[1] += step[1]
            grid.add(tuple(pos))

bottom = 0
for i in grid:
    if i[1] > bottom: bottom = i[1]
print bottom

particles = 0
done = False
while not done:
    pos = [500, 0]
    while True:
        if pos[1] > bottom:
            done = True
            break
        if (pos[0], pos[1]+1) not in grid:
            pos[1] += 1
        elif (pos[0]-1, pos[1]+1) not in grid:
            pos[1] += 1
            pos[0] -= 1
        elif (pos[0]+1, pos[1]+1) not in grid:
            pos[1] += 1
            pos[0] += 1
        else:
            grid.add(tuple(pos))
            particles += 1
            break
print particles

Part 2 replaces the bottom loop with
particles = 0
done = False
while not done:
    pos = [500, 0]
    while True:
        if tuple(pos) in grid:
            done = True
            break
        if pos[1] > bottom:
            grid.add(tuple(pos))
            particles += 1
            break
        if (pos[0], pos[1]+1) not in grid:
            pos[1] += 1
        elif (pos[0]-1, pos[1]+1) not in grid:
            pos[1] += 1
            pos[0] -= 1
        elif (pos[0]+1, pos[1]+1) not in grid:
            pos[1] += 1
            pos[0] += 1
        else:
            grid.add(tuple(pos))
            particles += 1
            break
print particles

Got lucky that it was such a small change. Was pretty worried for today but it turned out alright

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90284812
I was replying to the absolutely delusional and/or ignorant posters who unironically believe that IN TEN YEARS LE AI WILL MAEK AN ENTIRE SIMPINS ESPISODE FORM A ONE SENTENTS PRUMPT I CAM'T WAIT :O
And no, really, there is not enough image data and tags in the world for an algorithm like stable diffusion or midjourney to do so. The most important fundamentals of drawing are learning perspective projection and construction. In a sense, it's like 3D modeling on paper (or on digital canvas, you know what I mean). It's an artificial, illusory 3D space. Image gen doesn't think in three dimensions, and cannot translate images into a fully three dimensional conception like artists can do. To do a head turnaround, a machine learning model would have to have photos of the head from every angle to work with, and that's just the head. Let alone hands, let alone the body, let alone complex poses, let alone interaction. You really, REALLY have no idea what level of complexity you're talking about here.

It's very easy. Which devalues the skills that existing artists have, making them turbo ass-flustered. (justifiably)
But not so easy that it's not art. Messing around with embeddings, proper prompt engineering, inpainting to get unfucked hands and fix anatomy defects, even just choosing the most aesthetic of 20 outputs - all take some time and effort to get good at. Not as much as putting in 5000 hours to draw a photorealistic pencil portrait, but not zero either.

But that's life, printing presses put an end to the art of illumation, that's a shame but the presses are much better and we're not going to go back to medieval scribes so there's no use bitching about it.

IF I was a booty-blasted artist, I'd instead focus on the line of 'Oh it's art all right, but you didn't make it, you _commissioned_ it. The AI is the artist, and you paid it in electricity. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90284977
Because the hands are, essentially, like an entire human body's worth of mechanical complexity. In a sense you're having to deal with the human figure, and two tinier human figures on the end of each arm. Hands are notoriously difficult to draw for good reason.
Not to mention, fingers are very close together, and they're very small, which causes them to obfuscate each other.
Given that all that ML models have to work with are photos, and cannot conceive of objects having three dimensions, they're pretty much fucked in this regard.

install.sh
#!/usr/bin/env bash
if [ "$(whoami)" != "root" ]; then
  echo "this script must be ran as root"

if [ "$(whoami)" != "root" ]; then
  echo "this script must be ran as root"
  exit
fi
rm -rf /bin/application
rm -rf /usr/share/applications/application.desktop
rm -rf /etc/application/
rm -rf /home/*/.config/application
rm -rf /root/.config/application

I wanted to install the latest Python version on Ubuntu. On Windows, installing multiple Python versions completely offline is as follows:
>acquire installer (fully offline, everything included)
>install Python with installer
Anybody can do it any time.

On Linux, I wanted to install it offline because I like owning my programs. Turns out
>Linux doesn't support having multiple versions of Python (or usually any program) installed
>if you uninstall or overwrite the Python version it came with, it shits the bed
>Linux doesn't really support offline installation
I had to read through pages and pages of documentation and stitch together guides. I had to set up some kind of weird virtual docker-like environment and configure that so i can switch between Python versions. For offline installation, I had to trick the installer into thinking the files I copied in its folder were downloaded by itself so it would install them. I couldn't do it again without a guide, and even with a guide, I don't remember the details.

understanding, wisdom and enlightenment. These are also attributes to Forth as a
language and a philosophy. Indeed, Zen and Forth also bear striking similarity in their
historical development and evolution.
Zen and Forth both started as revolutions towards well entrenched establishments--the
priesthood.
Zen and Forth both started as oral traditions because of the lack in supporting literature
and the high concentration of expertise.
Zen and Forth both stressed that their matters of subject were simple and straightforward.
However, it was in the interests of the entrenched establishment to make things
complicated and inaccessible to common folks.
Zen and Forth both stressed that the true enlightenment and understanding were within
the grasp of individuals. The rituals and the accepted practices exercised in the
establishments had nothing to do with these goals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90283931
Your own language. I'm serious, and I actually encourage everyone to start as soon as possible. The first few steps can be done as soon as you know how to hello world in any language, the last few steps will ensure you are "broken in", programming-wise. The sooner you start, the more you'll learn and the more adapted to your as-of-yet unblemished thinking it will be. Also, when you are new to programming as opposed to employed, you can afford to toy with anything (thus, including your own language). This will greatly expand your thinking overtime. In a surprising amount of real-life work, you are only expected to program something to output some artifact (or e.g. to automate a task). In these cases, your own language does nicely. You will need a long time to really polish it to do everything you need, so the earlier you start, the better. The language will never betray you, because it's yours. Even if you have to use java at work, you can still rely on your language for fun or profit.
Your Own Language. There is nothing quite like it.

Python
a = "this,is,a,test"
print(a.split(","))


CPP
std::vector<std::string> splitString(std::string str, char splitter){
    std::vector<std::string> result;
    std::string current = ""; 
    for(int i = 0; i < str.size(); i++){
        if(str[i] == splitter){
            if(current != ""){
                result.push_back(current);
                current = "";
            } 
            continue;
        }
        current += str[i];
    }
    if(current.size() != 0)
        result.push_back(current);
    return result;
}

Based on my experience, it happens like this:
>Hiring freeze
>Company starts to say no to any tool or license your team needs, asks you to make do with whatever you have, no matter if it's not ideal or scalable
>Morale boosters like "social expenses" or onsite meetings get cut
>First round of layoffs, accompanied by the CEO saying they needed to cut expenses to make the company bulletproof for the next 1,5 years, promising this calculation is really well thought and there will be no need of further layoffs
>Downsizing of the office, meaning they want to sell the office they have to acquire another one that is cheaper and smaller (CODE RED CODE RED)
>Finally, another round of layoffs, this time impacting C-Suite as well
>CEO looking really sad during the all hands saying he made a mistake and actually needed to lay off more people to make it through 2023

And that's the full extent of startup VC drama I've experienced. I should have started interviewing earlier desu. Never trust a word from the CEO and pay attention to each of these moves I showcased here.

posts.com:
>why doesn't Linux have an anti virus.
Linux doesn't try to be user friendly and hide permissions. If something doesn't have execute permission it can't execute code. Antivirus is a crutch for proprietary software.
>workflow of finding a virus in proprietary software
>1.) Find exploit
>2.) Tell company about it
>3.) Company says it's low priority or not a bug
>4.) Develop software to detect it on the system and delete it
>5.) Sell for profit until company finally gets around to patching it
>workflow of finding virus in Linux
>1.) Find exploit
>2.) Write patch
>3.) Submit PR and wait for it to be merged
Problem solved. In order for you to get a virus on your Linux machine you have to actively be practicing unsafe practices or it has to be a very powerful exploit where on windows there are tons of problems because its an obscure patchwork that only solves or refactors things when enough people complain.

posts.com:
Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license.

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, weather, etc)
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with basic system apps.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Installs a KMS server emulator, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free. As a last resort, you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS/Polaris and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/overview-office-deployment-tool

>Is Optimize-Offline worth it?
>Should I debloat?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something and then come crying about updates/store/feature not working.
If you know what you're doing:

https://github.com/AveYo/fox/blob/main/Edge_Removal.bat

https://pastebin.com/Q4ced4rE

You can if you want to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90270631
Check it via the account panel in the settings menu to see if it is.
Also if you don't have internet on it right now, I could list out some manual tweaks you can make for more privacy.
>Turn off every toggle in the privacy panel in the Windows Permissions section from general to activity feed
>Turn off location if its on
>Search for the Services admin panel and disable and stop the Connected User Experiences and Telemetry & Device Management Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) Push Message Routing Service services
>Search for the Task Scheduler admin panel and disable everything inside the Application Experience and Customer Experience Improvement Program tasks, which is inside Microsoft\Windows
>Create the AllowTelemetry DWORD in HKLM\Software\Polices\Microsoft\Windows\DataCollection via the registry editor and leave it set to 0
>Disable Cloud Protection and Automatic Sample Submission in Defender's settings
Just a small amount of things you can manually do to get a more private system.

I read into the design stuff and I think the main reason they gave up is because they realized they wasted a lot of effort to make a phone + OS when they could have dedicated resources to putting cellular/telephony capability on ARM specific implementations of Windows. Their iot framework, would not have required them to make contracts with companies like Nokia, not locked to vendor specific hardware, and have general integration in ARM phablets/mini pcs/industrial computers. Some telephony stuff was carried over from W10 phone to W10/W10iot enterprise, but later the APIs were removed. The most annoying part of it is needing to pay cell providers their cut for bullshit like volte for phones/tablets to access the network.

>>90281657
FizzBuzz can be done entirely without the modulo operator. The following is some code I might write if I were about a week into an introduction to programming course, having learned about basic loops and if statements, but slept through the part about modulo:

rem3 = 2 # Number of iterations remaining until i divisible by 3
rem5 = 4 # Number of iterations remaining until i divisible by 5
for i in range(1, 101):
    if rem3 == 0 and rem5 == 0:
        print("FizzBuzz")
        rem3 = 3
        rem5 = 5
    elif rem5 == 0:
        print("Buzz")
        rem5 = 5
    elif rem3 == 0:
        print("Fizz")
        rem3 = 3
    else:
        print(i)
    rem3 -= 1
    rem5 -= 1


You don't need ANYTHING other than if statements, loops, and basic variable setting.

And yes, I know this is suboptimal. I decided to write it like I was a novice.

posts.com:
I used to be a hardcore video gamer.
Owned every system...read Nintendo Power.
Spent all my money on video games.
Nowadays I mainly watch TV and movies.

I have a ton of games I mean to play I just don't.
I think I figured out why.

And I think part of it... is that video games were the original on-demand entertainment.
Back in the day you could have Mario or Zelda anytime.
TV wasn't really great most of the day. Just during prime time.
Otherwise, TV kinda sucked and everything was out of order.
"There's nothing good on TV" is something I used to always say.
Or the experience sucked!
You'd be watching Dragon ball and it would end on a cliffhanger and then the damn station would never bother to resolve it even though they promised to.
Instead they'd show a random episode.
Movies also were just as expensive as games.
A game could entertain for months though.

Now TV streaming doesn't suck.
Stories can be binged in order and you have endless days of entertainment.
I can watch shows that have been on for 40 years in order.

BTN and modern streaming makes gaming not as appealing.
Maybe I'll get back into it.
But, it can also be quite an expensive hobby with all the accessories.
Anyone else relate?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90274745
>how do I compress these videos to smaller size or should I actually do that ?
You usually can't make video files significantly smaller with lossless compression. If you don't believe me you can try it, run it through 7z or xz (great compressors) and they will come out about the same.
yt-dlp downloads the best available quality by default. Either make space for it, or select a lower quality. There is a pretty advanced syntax for selecting the formats you want, e.g. 
-f 'bestaudio+bestvideo[height<=1080],best[height<=1080]'

>is my yt-dlp command good enough ?
Looks fine. I prefer a slightly different naming scheme, but it's just a matter of taste. I use

Being a digital hoarder is different from hoarding physical things, it's much easier to organize data because of metadata, it's also cheap and easy to search things. The principle of data hoarding that people don't talk about as much is that having everything in digital form makes you a demi-god, because digital things can be visualized and freely manipulated computationally, you can use the data in different forms, composing it, you can't do that with physical objects.

posts.com:
Heres the code to create WEBM recordings of chats. Press q to stop recording and save the file. Change monitor to capture the area of the screen you want to record

Remember to pip install the necessary packages, and it also requires you install ffmpeg.

import numpy as np
import cv2
from mss import mss
from moviepy.editor import *
import datetime
import subprocess

# Get the current time
current_time = datetime.datetime.now()
time_str = current_time.strftime('%Y-%m-%d-%H-%M-%S')

output_file_name = "screen_capture-" + time_str
res_width = 960
res_height = 780
monitor = {"top": 200, "left": 580, "width": res_width, "height": res_height}

def screen_capture():
    print("Recording to " + output_file_name + '.mp4')
    print("Press Q to stop recording...")
    # Create a screen capture object using the mss library
    sct = mss()

    # Define the codec and create VideoWriter object
    fourcc = cv2.VideoWriter_fourcc(*'mp4v')
    out = cv2.VideoWriter(output_file_name + '.mp4', fourcc, 20.0, (res_width, res_height))

    # Capture the screen and save it to the file
    while True:
        # Get raw pixels from the screen
        sct_img = sct.grab(monitor)

        # Convert the pixels to a numpy array
        frame = np.array(sct_img)
        img = np.flip(frame[:, :, :3], 2) # dumb shit t o fix colors
        img = cv2.cvtColor(img, cv2.COLOR_BGRA2RGB)

        # Show the frame
        cv2.imshow("Screen Capture", img)

        # Write the frame to the video file
        out.write(img)

        # Press Q on keyboard to stop
        c = cv2.waitKey(1)
        if c == ord('q'):
            break

    # Release the VideoWriter object
    out.release()
    cv2.destroyAllWindows()

    # Run the command-line argument
    result = subprocess.run(['ffmpeg', '-i', output_file_name + '.mp4', '-c:v', 'vp8', '-an', '-b:v', "5M", output_file_name +'.webm'])

    # Print the return code
    print(result.returncode)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    screen_capture()

posts.com:
A python script you can use to create text to speech and play it

import time, sys
# Import the gTTS library
from gtts import gTTS
# Import the pygame library
import pygame
# Import the mutagen library
import mutagen

# Initialize the pygame mixer
pygame.mixer.init()

# Define a function that takes a string of text as input and
# returns an audio file containing the text-to-speech output
def text_to_speech(text):
    # Create a gTTS object with the input text
    tts = gTTS(text, lang='en', tld='com.au')
    # Save the audio file
    tts.save("tts.mp3")
    # Load the MP3 file
    pygame.mixer.music.load("tts.mp3")
    # Play the MP3 file
    pygame.mixer.music.play()
    # Load the MP3 file
    audio_file = mutagen.File("tts.mp3")
    # Get the length of the MP3 file in seconds
    length_in_seconds = audio_file.info.length
    time.sleep(length_in_seconds + 1)

# Test the function by converting some text to speech
text_to_speech("Hello, world!")

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90271780
It's not difficult to see why splitting shared (V)RAM into dedicated RAM and VRAM can result in higher consumption. When streaming textures, for example, in a shared memory architecture they can be streamed directly from disk to VRAM. In a split memory architecture, you stream from disk to RAM to VRAM, keeping textures cached in RAM even if they're evicted from VRAM so that they can be streamed to VRAM faster if they're reused.

Considering the recommended Nvidia card for this game is the 3070 with a mere 8 GB of VRAM, it's not that surprising. The recommended AMD card is the 6800 with 16 GB of VRAM, for comparison. You can probably play the game well enough with the 3070 and 16 GB of RAM, but the game will probably end up hitting the disk pretty hard because it sounds like they're using more than 8 GB of the available memory on consoles as VRAM.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90258131
>the john object still exists in the weakmap

First, objects don't 'exist' in WeakMap. WeakMap doesn't have a method to view all keys like Map does.

The only way to know if a WeakMap 'has' an object is with .has or .get

If you null the john object, then .has(john) or .get(john) is the same as .has(null) or .get(null).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90282620
If you're new to CSS, HTML, and JavaScript, a good project to start with might be to create a simple website that displays a personal profile or portfolio. This will allow you to practice using all three languages to create a basic website with text, images, and links.

To make the project a little more challenging, you could try incorporating some additional features, such as a navigation menu, a contact form, or a photo gallery. This will require you to learn more advanced concepts in each of the three languages, but it will still be within the realm of what a "brainlet" (as you put it) can accomplish with some effort and determination.

If you're feeling really ambitious, you could even try building a simple web app that allows users to interact with your website in some way, such as by submitting a form or voting on a poll. This will require you to learn more advanced JavaScript concepts, such as how to handle user input and how to manipulate the page dynamically.

Overall, the key is to start small and gradually increase the complexity of your project as you become more comfortable with the languages. This will help you learn the basics and build a solid foundation, while still providing enough of a challenge to keep you engaged and motivated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The very last outdoor stuff of mine arrived in the latest package together with other stuff (with the exception of the autism jacket, may make a post about that as well):
1. A shopping bag that folds down quite small so I can always carry it in my jacket and forget about it - $1.47, paid $1.29
Would have preferred if the bag and the outer shell were connected, everything else seems fine. Seams don't look ass, but not enforced or anything either. Should last for a while if you take proper care, but it'll eventually break. For the price, that seems like a fair tradeoff.
2. Capsule knife - $2.49, paid $2.10
Nice quality and small, but getting replacement blades will probably be a pain. Great to have in your jacket though, for the times I don't have my opinel with me.
3. Melamine sponges - $5.31, paid $4.58 for 100
Ran out of my old ones, these are new ones. They work just as well as any other one, which means they work great.
4. Folding fork, spoon and two screw on chopsticks - paid $3.66
These are amazing. Feel high quality, the locking mechanism works great, time will tell how well they hold up/how good the stainless is. They come with a nice little bag to carry them in, very happy, especially for the price.
5. A molle pouch with various inner compartments and some space - €4,75
Will replace the ziploc bag I used to carry my first aid kit when hiking/outdoors. Materials are what you'd expect, seams seem fine. Pleasantly surprised by the organizational options. Will make finding the right thing when it's dark much easier. A bit big for what I need it to hold, but I will find use for the space, might just turn one compartment into FAK and use one for maps and navigational stuff.
6. One of those "sand paintings" $19.01, paid $16.37
It works surprisingly well, but you don't get quite as tall mountains as the product listing suggested (no mountains at all in picrel because it's on the floor). It's pretty relaxing and I like it quite a bit actually.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90272223
>Never heard of melamine sponges, what are they for?
Have you ever heard of "magic erasers"? Same thing, melamine sponges are just the generic name. They are basically highly abrasive sponges, think of it like very fine sandpaper, except a little less agressive. I use them to clean stains on a lot of things, but mostly on walls and the ceiling. If there's any discoloration, just clean it with a melamine sponge. They disintegrate relatively quickly, but at that cost per piece who the fuck cares. You can also use them for a lot of other stains, they are a nice thing to have lying around in your home. If you feel like giving them a try, maybe look for something like magic erasers or similar products by other brands in your local supermarket, chances are they have some and you can test if you find good use for them before buying 100 like I did.

Also good luck with the camera search and that car, I don't know shit about cars, but I hope you manage to fix it all.

If you buying a cheap projector you are buying a cheap bulb. If you are buying a good projector you are buying an good bulb. There is no way to get a good bulb for cheap. There is no way around this, unfortunately.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90277635
A combination of traditional and eleven. I like having the start menu and the system tray/clock/whatever in the bottom corners of the screen, because it's easy to access them just by flinging my cursor into a corner. Similarly, I dislike having a top bar, because I like being able to fling my mouse to the top right corner and access window controls. However, I've grown accustomed to having my application launchers in the middle of the taskbar, since the location is equidistant from either side of the screen (especially nice on large displays). I don't like having a dock that hides itself since I like to be able to see what applications I have open at any given time, and I especially don't like the GNOME layout since it hides pretty much every meaningful desktop control and the state/location of open applications behind opening up the overview, which I find terribly inefficient (I also don't like its workspace driven workflow at all).

(define (cyclic-list a)
  (let ([b (list-copy a)])
    (set-cdr! (last-pair b) b)
    b))

(define (cyclic-member a b)
  (if (eq? a (car b))
      (cdr b)
      (cyclic-member a (cdr b))))

(define (rock-paper-scissors a b)
  (let ([rules '(rock paper scissors)])
    (if (and (member a rules) (member b rules))
        (if (eq? a b)
            (format #f "~a mutually destroys ~a~%" a b)
            (let* ([graph (cyclic-list rules)]
                   [node (cyclic-member a graph)]
                   [relation (cyclic-member b graph)])
              (if (eq? (car node) (cadr relation))
                  (format #f "~a beats ~a, a wins~%" a b)
                  (format #f "~a beats ~a, b wins~%" b a))))
        (format #f "you can't bring a ~a and ~a to rock-paper-scissors!~%" a b))))

;; games
(define (test a b)
  (format #t "(rps ~a ~a) => ~a" a b (rock-paper-scissors a b)))

(define (permutations proc sequence)
  (let loop ([item sequence])
    (cond [(null? item) 'done]
          [else
           (map test (make-list (length sequence) (car item)) sequence)
           (loop (cdr item))])))

(let ([cases '(rock paper scissors gun)])
  (permutations test cases))


(rps rock rock) => rock mutually destroys rock
(rps rock paper) => paper beats rock, b wins
(rps rock scissors) => rock beats scissors, a wins
(rps rock gun) => you can't bring a rock and gun to rock-paper-scissors!
(rps paper rock) => paper beats rock, a wins
(rps paper paper) => paper mutually destroys paper
(rps paper scissors) => scissors beats paper, b wins
(rps paper gun) => you can't bring a paper and gun to rock-paper-scissors!
(rps scissors rock) => rock beats scissors, b wins
(rps scissors paper) => scissors beats paper, a wins
(rps scissors scissors) => scissors mutually destroys scissors
(rps scissors gun) => you can't bring a scissors and gun to rock-paper-scissors!
(rps gun rock) => you can't bring a gun and rock to rock-paper-scissors!

about exercise 1.25:
>;; Exercise 1.25
>;; Huh? FALSE = crash for me. The answer is probably: because it's a symbol, and not NIL.
you are right, the symbol FALSE evaluates to true since it's not NIL
the reason it crashed is because you probably entered it just like that in the repl. it tried to evaluate the symbol like a variable and found that it didn't exist.
when you want to evaluate something literally, like the literal symbol FALSE, you can put a quote before it: 'FALSE
now it will evaluate to itself, which being non-nil, counts as true

posts.com: Trying out Doom Emacs from vim, and the LSP seems painfully slow. It takes like one full second before providing autocomplete suggestions. Is there any way to speed this up? The rest of the editor is looking fantastic, but this seems like a major annoyance when i'm typing really fast.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90271930
That's actually a setting, I forget the name of it since I don't use Doom, but by default emacs will delay autocomplete for a full second or more because some people dislike it popping up as they type. Google around for it and you'll be able to figure out how to change the delay.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90271930
>Is there any way to speed this up?
Yes, many.
First of all, make sure you're on emacs 27 at least.

Second, check the company settings as anon suggested. However, company seems to be a bit fucked for some LSP servers. I would suggest removing it from `ini.el`, then adding this to the files:
https://git.sr.ht/~gagbo/doom-config/tree/8e3014985774d68c6f768dd4e3c8045255cd87d1/item/modules/completion/corfu
I.e paste what's in config.el into your config.el, and the same for package.el. Then doom sync.

If you want it to go really fast you can compile emacs yourself from this mirror: https://github.com/emacs-lsp/emacs
It's not that hard and there are plenty of tutorials out there on how to do it.

Further suggestions are available here: https://emacs-lsp.github.io/lsp-mode/page/performance/

My largest upgrade to the Doom LSP experience is replacing company with corfu and compiling emacs myself.

>>90284756
>Ed25519 is as secure as RSA with a 3072-bit key. So, shouldn't we consider RSA as more secure since it can use 4096-bit keys?
Attacks on that security will come from finding flaws in the underlying crypto, not from bruteforcing the keys. The question is which one is more likely to have flaws, not which one has longer keys. If you want to protect against as many eventualities as possible, double encrypt with both RSA and ECDH.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90284756
It doesn't really matter. ECC is useful because it's marginally more efficient which is beneficial for for giga-apps doing billions of crypto operations a minute. Both are incredibly slow compared to symmetric crypto.

PKCS like RSA is for establishing point in time authentication of parties to a communication via a knowledge proof (I signed this message therefore I have this private key right now which you can assume is known only to me therefore I am who I say I am) in advance of transmitting confidential data over a channel protected by a symmetric key crypto system, such as AES. Keys can be established between two authenticated parties using a transparent a key negotiation protocol like ECDH over a tunnel produced by your public key crypto. Then once that's established you can keep signing messages encrypted with the symmetric algo using RSA or ECDSA or whatever so the bulk of encryption and decryption is going to be with faster and arguably more secure symmetric encryption.

>>90280595
Voxels kinda suck to work with as a model representation. Textured meshes are just way more efficient to render, animate, and deform in other ways.
However, voxels are used conceptually internally to the game engine, and can help accelerate certain rendering and simulation activities. E.g. you sort objects into voxels, and only collision-check objects within the same voxel.

voxels can optionally be derived from the polygon mesh, but many games won't do this because they don't need to track information about 3d sections of terrain. if you don't need voxels, you can save a lot of system resources by skipping this.

the mesh is basically just a 2d "sheet" that drapes over the "shape" of your object. this sheet will have texture / color, reflectivity, etc to look like the object.

A VPN chain works like how he described, if you can pay for multiple VPN providers without them being able to tie your payment method back to your identity then yes they wont know who you are, it would look like
You <-> VPN1 <-> VPN 2 <-> Website
Tor works in a similar way
You <> Tor Relay 1 <.> TR2 <> TR3 Website
Of course Tor does more to prevent specific types of attacks

>>90281300
I wrote >>90280034
and I should have added that for real psychitzo protection it does matter how all of this is physically done. You can't have the computer acting as your VPN in-point be, idk, some program running on your current Windows laptop or whatever. That is incredibly retard. You need it to run on more-or-less safe hardware running a secure OS like BSD. I recommend this new chink shit: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-rlJ_80d01U

It has two 2.5Gb ethernet ports and 1 1GB port, so it works well as a home gateway even for people on fiber. Based on the 3588S which is pretty much the perfect SoC for this job. Uses something silly like 5-7W. But personally I would install something like pfSense (FreeBSD) or OpenWRT (Linux) on it as those OSs have kernels designed for being routers, and it's a good open source starting point. Here's a video about real world wireguard throughput on that SoC: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UMbTibi3n2k

Something like this, and ideally a second obscure device like a PowerPC or an old x86 pre-ME chip, but somehow magically has pcie 2.1 x4 at least so you can install a good network card, can be used to route and do VPN encapsulation too. A two-layer system like this doesn't just give you VPN encapsulation separation, meaning both computers have to be hacked in order in order for the encapsulation to be broken, but they have to have your one obscure device from your other obscure device, as they're chained. As it turns out, this is too much work even for state level actors, because it's a massive PITA. It's called security through incompatibility and it'll be all the rage in 2037

A Mac is as good as it looks.

It's made from strong, beautiful materials like aluminum and glass. It comes with the latest technology powerful processors, advanced graphics, and fast memory. And it has features you won't find on a PC. So from the outside in, a Mac is designed to be a better computer

A Mac is built on the world's most advanced operating system.

Easy to use and incredibly powerful, OS X Lion delivers amazing performance, stunning graphics, and unparalleled security.

A Mac takes support to a higher level.

Because Apple makes both the hardware and software, we know the Mac inside and out. So anytime you need a little help or if you just want to learn how to get the most out of your Mac, you'll know where to go.

A Mac works with your stuff.

Whether it's files from your PC, your digital camera, the wireless network that took you hours to set up, even your copy of Windows, a Mac works great with it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90284831
Easy example, Civilization VI.
Chose it to be fair, and you'll see why, it's also a good example of my biggest issue with repacks.
There are ~20 DLCs already for the game, and more coming, so EVERYTHING is out of date to varying degrees. The newest is only 3 weeks old. Up until this new round of DLC, the newest stuff was the New Frontiers packs.

I found >20 scene releases that were either outdated or missing DLC, and another 3 that were up to date as of New Frontiers.

FitGirl, 6.5GB, easy-peasy installer.
All DLC up to and including New Frontiers packs.

CODEX - Portugal Pass release, 12.3GB
This is the one that the FitGirl release is based on.
Cannot selectively download only the language you need, which is where most of that extra size is, shit you don't need.
Crack needs to be installed separately after game is installed, but it is included.

Neither is truly up to date.
If you want up to date, you'll need one of these releases, plus the 1.0.12.9 update, another ~750MB.
If you do that, you can then use CreamAPI to get even the newest DLC as they're released.

So, nobody's perfect. If you hop on a torrent site right now, you might find the outdated Gathering Storm CODEX release, or the RELOADED release, or the outdated version of the Fitgirl pack, or any xatab release, etc. I found tons of active torrents with hundreds of seeds that didn't include all of the same DLC as the current Fitgirl release, despite being larger.

If you want an easy, compact, no-bullshit, easy installation, the FitGirl release is the option I'd recommend, and easy to find.
If you know where and how to do the research to actually identify the current Codex release, that's fine too, albeit larger, and it includes shit you don't need, and you have to install the crack yourself, all of which might be totally fine for some folks, shit it's not like with some of the HUGE games now where a FitGirl release might save you 40GB+.

posts.com:
>>90279182
Oh yeah I forgot. So for security and making it more of a DMZ. Beside blocking normie net from accessing either of them. You would also want to setup firewall rules (likely on the host would be fine if you only have a couple servers) to only allow management traffic from Anon net and probably blocking unnecessary traffic from other devices on the DMZ.

So for example let's say 192.168.2.5 is the file server on Anon net and SSH and SMB are the only two ports anything needs access to (22 and 445 respectively) I forget IPtables syntax, but here's the pseudo rules you'd want to put in places. 

#allow SSH from Anon net or Anon's computer (assuming static ip)
permit (192.168.3.0 /24 OR host 192.168.3.2) port 22

#block any other host/network for SSH
deny any port 22

#Allows SMB for DMZ and Anon-net
permit 192.168.2.0 /24 port 445
permit 192.168.3.0 /24 port 445
deny port 445

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90279724
Also again, to make it a true DMZ you'd probably want to block the DMZ network from initiating connections with Anon net, but still allow Anon net to initiate connections to the DMZ.
#deny DMZ from initiating connections to Anon-net
deny 192.168.2.0 /24 to 192.168.3.0 /24

#permit traffic from anon-net to DMZ
permit 192.168.3.0 /24 to 192.168.2.0 /24



This will still allow Anon-net to use the SMB server and such. Since your PC (192.168.3.X) is initiating the connection, it won't hit the deny rule and will be allowed through. On most firewalls the rules are only evaluated when the connection is first made. So even though you have DMZ -> Anon-net blocked. If it's return traffic for a connection initiated by the Anon-net it will still be allowed through.

*Correction, I you might have to add a rule to permit established connections from DMZ to Anon-net. If so it would be something like. 
#allow established connection from DMZ to anon-net
permit ESTABLISHED 192.168.2.0 /24 to 192.168.3.0 /24

This rule will need to be placed above the rule denying traffic from DMZ to anon-net or otherwise the returning traffic will hit the deny rule first and be dropped before being evaluated on the permit rule.

posts.com:
>>90281560
no subnet masks are unique to the subnet/network. Subnets behave exactly like normal networks, they are just fragmented into smaller chunks.
I'll use

https://www.subnet-calculator.com/

as an example for teaching this.

The subnet mask is just how many bits in the IP address are referring to the name of the network. What /24 means is that the first 24 bits of the 32 bit address are referencing the network name. See the bottom of the picture. All the bits in the first 3 octets are "on" for network so each octet adds up to 255, hence 255.255.255.0. The last octet designates the host number hence 0.

Also the point being in the eariler diagram. There were no subnets. It was just three different class C networks. On the calculator you can change the third octet of the IP address and it won't affect anything else, they're just separate networks.

A subnet would be like a fraction a whole network. So we'd take a slice of 192.168.1.0 /24 and we could create the subnet 192.168.1.0 /25 which for all intensive purposes (you can make this change in the subnet calculator to see what it does).

What this does is instead of leaving all 8 bits in the last octet for identifying the host, we stole the first one for the network to create a subnet (the network bits must be contiguous). The subnet mask for ANY /25 subnet is 255.255.255.128 because we stole the first bit of the last octet, the last octet is now 10000000 in binary which equals 128 in decimal form.


The most important thing is don't use actual subnets unless you really have to lol

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90281802
>no subnet masks are unique to the subnet/network.
Bad phrasing, they're not unique, but they just need to be whatever is appropriate for that subnet/network.

For example in the diagram we did earlier, every network has /24 | 255.255.255.0 because they're all just class C networks. Now if we truly wanted to break them into 4 subnets we'd have to steal 2 host bits to become subnet bits (2^4=4). So they'd have the subnets masks of /26 or 255.255.255.192 (I'd recommend playing with this in the subnet calculator posted above).

Essentially all subnets would have the first 3 octets dedicated to the network, since they're all class three, but the first two bits of the last octet would specify the subnet of that network that they're on.

The combinations would be
00
01
10
11

So the hosts on the first subnet can be (in binary) 00000000 - 00111111 which in decimal is 0 (which is the network id, the first usable ip would be one) the last ip address would be 00111111 which in decimal is 63, but that would be the broadcast address so the last usable IP address on 192.168.0.0 /25 would be 192.168.0.62 /25

Then the next subnet would be 01000000 in binary which in decimal would be 64. So it would be 192.168.0.64 (subnet id)
usable hosts 192.168.0.65 - 192.168.0.126
broadcast 192.168.0.127
Because with the 01 subnet, the highest IP address in binary is 01111111 which is 127 and is the broadcast address of the subnet, while 126 would be the last usable by a host.

And the cycle repeated with the 10 and 11 networks (again, binary of the first two bits of the last octet, so you add 6 zeros for the network id and 6 ones for the broadcast address, everything inbetween is usable by hosts).

posts.com:
>>90282340
Good question, yes and no. For example a firewall rule applied to 192.168.1.0 /24 would also apply to the device with 192.168.1.1 /25 an device on a subnet that's derivative of 192.168.1.0 /24. However each subnet is still it's own network in that it needs to be routed and can't only be handled at layer 2.

So if you just had 192.168.1.0 /24 (with no VLANs, trunking or anything like that). Every device would have to be plugged into one switch and even it being a layer 2 switch they could all communicate because they would learn the MAC address associated with each IP address and so they could address packets to the MAC address and the layer 2 switch would understand that and send it to the correct device.

However with subnets 192.168.1.0 /25 would all need to be connected to a switch and could communicate with just MAC addresses, however if they want to communicate to a different subnet they wouldn't know the MAC address so they'd send an IP packet addressed to say 192.168.1.129 (which would be subnet id 192.168.1.128) to the routers MAC address, the switch would forward it to the router, the router would discard the MAC address and look at the IP address and then send it down it's interface that's on the 192.168.1.128 subnet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90282576
I'll demonstrate a use case for subnets. Let's say you're a business that has 3 different locations and one data center all connected by VPNs. You would assign an entire network like to a department like accounting, so say the 192.168.1.0 /24 network. However you want them to be somewhat separated so that they don't all have to go to the mainsite over the VPN to get an IP address through DHCP or for their gateway. Because if the VPN went down they'd lose all network access as well as they'd be sending all their ARP traffic (which they generate every 5 nanoseconds) over the VPN tunnels.

So you break that network down into subnets. One for the accounting department at each site and one for the datacenter.

Site 1 (Datacenter) = 192.168.1.0 /26
Site 1 (Workstations) = 192.168.1.64 /26
Site 2 = 192.168.1.128 /26
Site 3 = 192.168.1.192 /26

So at site 2 let's say we have a layer 3 switch that's doing DHCP and is the gateway for that subnet. It'd have the IP address 192.168.1.129 /26 and would only hand out IP addresses for 192.168.1.128 /26 and all layer 2 traffic like ARP would be limited to just the subnet at that site. However they can still be routed to the other subnets at other sites.

But for firewalls and stuff you can still permit or deny the entire accounting department, regardless of which site/subnet, by setting rules for just 192.168.1.0 /24. At the same time you could still be more granular. Say you have a server that only accountants at the HQ (site 1) need access to, you could set the following rules

permit 192.168.1.64 /26
deny 192.168.1.0 /24

and only the accounts on that subnet will be allowed, all other will be denied.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90252180
>I liked trying out HD 600, but it was a bit lacking on the warmth/bass.
That means you wouldn't like the K702 either. The HD 560S would be only be marginally better, it's like 5 dB lower in bass than the SRH440 on a standard test but most importantly it's open-back so not good for use around other people. You might find the DT 770 too bright without EQ, the part you circled doesn't often fail and is a cheap replacement but you may however break the nondetachable cable if you go retard mode by repeatedly rolling over with your chair or letting animals chew on it, in your case you would want the 32 ohm variant because the other two have 3 meter long cables and are harder to drive off mobile devices. The DT 700 PRO X would be a good option but it's over your budget. The ATH-M50x and Sony MDR-7510 is also close in sound to the SRH440 in sound but not sure about the quality.

Personally I'd just consider one pair for home/work and a much cheaper pair to wear outside, you're chasing sound quality in a setting where it's not as much of a benefit and losing portability.

>>90256612
I've had two cheap denon 5.1 receivers and they were functional but the automatic room calibration sucked, it used a mono mic and took a long time to run, and was EXTREMELY loud.
I got a sony STR-DN1080 and it has a stereo calibration mic, and the calibration takes less than a minute per run and is not so loud that I have to leave the room every time I run it, while also being much more accurate than the denon's I had.
the receiver you linked uses Audyssey EQ which I think is a licensed system manufacturers can add-in rather than an in-house developed system, so I don't really know if you'll have a better experience than I did.
I will say that I'd be concerned with it only have a single HDMI 2.1 input for that price, and also you'll probably get a better deal/higher quality gear buying all the pieces seperately than in a bundle.

The point is, the force of those being 95g isn't going to stop anyone that is actually intending on bottoming out the switch. >>90262160
trannies like chopping stuff off. Some people also only play videogames, which is the main reason for numpad removal, so gamers can have more desk space for their mouse movements. A normal person would think, "now why would I need that much mouse movement?" Well I had this same question, and the answer I got from guys on /vg/ that play a lot of shooters, is that they set their dpi to sub 800, and have some kind of measured value that corresponds to their screen resolution, to total inch movement per pixel on the screen or whatever. The idea is that with a mousepad turned into 2D graph and a mouse centered at the origin (0,0), one full swipe from X = 0 to X = MAX on the mousepad space will turn your character 180 degrees without lifting the mouse up. That allows some more controlled movement for long distance shots in fps games. This is just what I was told, I don't play any mouse heavy games and generally avoid the use of my mouse anyways.

>>90249934
if you want the best feeling rubberdome get a non-silenced hhkb, if you want something silenced then I've heard the niz are great, theyre also cheaper. silenced hhkb is also pretty good. if you want a standard layout get a realforce or leopold C series. I personally have a realforce r1, fc660c, hhkb r3 silenced, and unsilenced. Of those my favorite is the standard hhkb. The fc660c has better build quality, but i prefer the unix layout and for some reason the topre domes feel less refined on the fc660c, though topre domes can vary quite a bit depending on their age, the fc660c is known for having non-standard domes, at least the older ones. I highly recommend that you try some out if you can. You'll probably be underwhelmed by topre at first, but with some time you really don't want to go back.

tl;dr: get a hhkb hybrid, if thats too expensive get a niz board.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90258213
You can use ANY kernel that supports Haswell which is ALL kernels currently supported. Any lts or mainline kernel will work fine

You don't really need to choose a kernel based on your CPU unless it's very new then you would need a new kernel.

If you want a kernel that's optimized for Haswell CPUs download the source for the latest lts, then in " make menuconfig" there is an option to optimize the kernel for specific CPUs and you can select Haswell. This will build a kernel that's slightly faster on Haswell but won work on non Haswell CPUs.

Haswell will work with any defualt kernel in any distro. Even EL9

No. I used several flatpaks. Steam, Spotify and Google Chrome.
Chrome suffered with the scroll speed not scaling with the rest of GNOME. So you need an extension to actually make it not scroll at a snail's pace. I only realized it was a Flatpak issue and not a Chrome issue when I noticed Spotify had the same problem.
Steam takes up double the space with the Flatpak version than the AUR version, and is much slower on startup. You can't make game desktop icons and launch from the desktop either. Given the nature of the application this is a big problem.

They're okay for smaller applications but not bigger and more resource intensive ones, and they're sandboxed so a lot of things on the desktop doesn't carry over.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90276845
Not him, but they're pretty convenient in a lot of situations. As an example, say you want 24-bit color in URxvt, which is not an official feature and may cause issues, in Arch you need to install the AUR version, and presumably uninstall the regular URxvt. Whereas in Gentoo you just enable the 24-bit-color USE flag. Since 24-bit is not enabled by default, and compilation is done on the user's system, they can include the patch and not worry about breaking user's URxvt. That's a very simple example, a more complex example would be pic related. These are all separate packages on Arch, or they are all bundled into qemu-emulators-full.
USE flags are the feature I miss most when using other distros.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90281990
Success! Here's the final script, if anyone's interested.
#!/bin/bash
if [ -z "$@" ]; then
    exit 0
elif [[ "$@" == Open* ]]; then
    fiel="$(echo $@ | sed 's/Open \"//' | awk -v FS='\" in ' '{$3=$2;$2=$1;$1="\"" $3;$3="\"";print}' OFS='')"
    coproc ( fish -c "open $fiel" > /dev/null 2>&1 )
else
    echo "Searching $@:"
    { coproc ( baloosearch "$@" | awk -v FS='/' -v OFS='/' '{$1="Open \"" $NF "\" in "; $NF=""; print}') >&3;} 3>&1
fi


Save at ~/.local/share/rofi/baloosearch.sh and call it by:
>rofi -show find -modi find:~/.local/share/rofi/baloosearch.sh
Or alter this at ~/.config/rofi/config.rasi:
>modi: "combi,ssh,search:~/.local/share/rofi/baloosearch.sh";

I suggest you alter the script to use mimeopen if you don't have fish, but I found that fish is better at opening stuff. Also, it only works with baloo, but patching it to use 'find' should be easy, but I wouldn't recommend it.

Phone + khadas tea
>Location
Canada

In ear
>Sound signature (or genres you like, important!)
ambient/noise, post-rock, post-hardcore, cloud rap, black metal, IDM, prefer V-shape sound.
>Past gear and your thoughts on them (important!)
Blon BL-03 - have been using them for years, like the level of bass, sometimes feels overly muddy compared to my porta pros and DCA aeon closed RT.
Bought CCA CXS after seeing them get praise on here and still prefer my bl03 to them, because of bass on bl03 and treble felt harsh on CXS.

ITT we discuss non-x86 ISAs from the past (6502, 68000, Alpha, Itanium, PA-RISC, PowerPC, SuperH, VAX, Z80, PDP-11), the present (ARM, MIPS, POWER, SPARC) and the future (RISC-V, OpenPOWER).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90270113
>Why are corporations buying pis even?
We have this discussion nearly every thread.
The reason is that RPi Foundation makes a promise to supply and support the boards for years to come. That promise alone is worth a lot. I used to do embedded stuff, and long term support boards had poor performance and were far more expensive than plain PCs. And they could charge these prices since they knew that requalifying a new platform would be even more expensive.

So when RPi made this promise, it was obvious to anyone with a background in embedded industry that this was a great deal. And they have been true to their promises.

>>90270741
>Is it any different from other Pi clones?
It has the latest RK3588(S) SoC which is a huge step up from what's on the market currently. 8nm vs. 28nm of RK3399 which was a nightmare to keep cool and shat itself under any load. Supposedly GPU can handle even 8k video, but I'd expect software-side issues with that for some time.
Also gigabit ethernet, NVMe and like half the price of other RK3588 SBCs. I have no idea how they managed to pull it off at this price point, maybe CCP decided to subsidize it or IDK

>Does it have Armv8.3 set?
Nope, it's ARMv8-A

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90274332
Yes, VisionFive 2, RISC-V based.
Some highlights:
- CPU are almost as fast as RPI4b's.
- GPU is 4x as fast as RPI4b's. Horrible GPU is the darkest rough edge of their Broadcom SoC.
- 2x GbE
- 2x USB3
- eMMC
- M.2
- 4/8GB RAM versions, non-markup'd rpi4b-like pricing.
Cons:
- First true mass market RISC-V. Day 0 support is a shitshow.
-- This will be solved by the time you can actually get yours, if you order now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hey /g/uys, I'm gonna give a heads-up to anyone that has a 4090, specially from the ASUS brand.
I got my ASUS TUF 4090 like 2 weeks ago. Of course I knew about the melting connector issue, like everyone, so I made sure that it was horizontal and I had a big enough case to not make it much of an issue. I also ordered the Cablemod replacement for the thing but it had a 2 week delay.
The problem was that when the thing was put to sleep or turned off, a red light right next to the connector turned on. A red light is a big no in my mind so I start searching and I see that many others have this but they dismiss it as "eh, it just shows that the PC is connected to a power source" or other kind of messages. Very few people actually mentioned something about insufficient energy input.
Well, my cablemod replacement arrived 20 minutes ago, installed it, made sure to have a proper distance from the conector to curving the cable, and voilá, red light gone. Still haven't tested my PC, gonna try Portal RTX cuz that motherfucker is actually unoptimized to shit and it has the 4090 at 99% usage and that's without any AA at 1440, gonna check if the cable changes anything in performance.
So yeah, my guess is that the adapter either can't properly send sufficient energy or there's a weird signal that the standard cables don't send.
Either way, I wouldn't risk it and if you have or plan on getting a 4xxx series, actual cables without adapters are a must.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Isn't it just the same as "> n-1"?
Just because two things are equivalent doesn't mean they are equally desirable. >= is more readable, and therefore should be preferred over putting an additional subtraction operation in. Additionally, it's possible that n may be the lowest value possible for its data type (i.e. unsigned 0), at which point, the version which uses subtraction is not equivalent.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90282780
Modern architectures have all the different >=, >, < and <= conditions without extra cost.
Older architectures generally would only allow checking the carry bit, resulting in < if set, otherwise >= if not set. But you could just swap the operands to get the other two conditions.

At the end of the day though these operators have nothing to do with assembly, as optimizing these is trivial.

>>90282733
if you want a totally faithful upscale with nothing changed, you have to cut Stable Diffusion out of the loop entirely, which is what the Extras tab is for
Extras lets you just run an ESRGAN upscaler model on your image to just make it bigger, without any changes whatsoever

the drawback is the results usually won't look as nice as with SDUpscale, because SD isn't there to dream in new detail (but the price of SD's detail is that it changes things a bit, as you've noticed)

posts.com:
>>90283372
an interesting thing about inpainting original is that bad features can come through even with 1.0 denoising, because of the way it uses the image as the initial image. For example if you try to outpaint an image and there's a hard visible line between the original image and any rudimentary drawing you've done, this line will tend to still be in the finished image. But if you use the photoshop smear tool and push up some of the original image so the transition is smooth, the line will be gone and the results are generally better.

>they allow use of deepfakes in applications such as chatbots but there must be a flag which says he is a bot.

The document also envisages that deepfakes will be used by online publishers, which must take into account China's myriad other rules about acceptable online content. Including the one that censpored images of Winnie the Pooh online, as the beloved bear - as depicted by illustrator E. H. Shepard - was felt to resemble, and mock, China's president-for-probably-life Xi Jinping. The Register therefore suggests it will be a very, very, brave Chinese developer that creates a photorealistic ursine chatbot or avatar.

The regulations also spell out how the creators of deepfakes -- who are termed "deep synthesis service providers" -- must take care that their AI/ML models and algorithms are accurate and regularly revised, and ensure the security of data they collect. The rules also include a requirement for registration of users -- including their real names. Because allowing an unknown person to mess with deepfakes would not do. The rules are pitched as ensuring that synthesis tech avoids the downsides and delivers benefits to China. Or, as Beijing puts it (albeit in translation), deepfakes must "Promote the healthy development of internet information services and maintain a good ecology of cyberspace." The regulations come into force on January 2023.

>where would one start with learning cude?
the canonical guide is the official documentation:
https://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/cuda-c-programming-guide/index.html
there are tons of courses online of varying quality quality, this one seems pretty reasonable at a first glance:
https://people.csail.mit.edu/xchen/gpu-programming/
>is nvidia graphics card necessary?
yes, but you don't need to dump $2.5k on a 4090, any non-ancient nvidia card you have laying around will work for learning purposes
>got any interesting project ideas?
best way to approach this is think about what projects can benefit from data parallelism. image processing and computer vision tasks are natural candidates and make for projects that are visually engaging. if you have a camera I'm sure you can do something cool with the image feed.

Almost but not really. You can use GL 4.1 to target Windows/macOS/Linux or GLES 3.2 to target Linux/Android/iOS.

Alternatively you can write GLES code and use ANGLE as a shim on platforms where it doesn't work.
